In this note, we analyze the classical magneto-static approach to the theory of type I superconductors, and a Debye source representation that can be used numerically to solve the resultant equations. We also prove that one of the fields, J−, found within the superconductor via the London equations, is the physical current in that the outgoing part of the magnetic field is given as the Biot-Savart integral of J−. Finally, we compute the static currents for moderate values of London penetration depth, λL, for a sphere, a stellarator-like geometry and a two-holed torus.

sections.heading: 1 The Model
sections.text:
Suppose that the superconducting material is homogeneous, isotropic and occupies a region Ω ⊂ R3. Within Ω there is a magnetic field B−, and a current J−, which satisfy the London equations given by:
∇×B− = J− , and ∇× J− = − 1 λ2L B− . (1.1)
The constant λL is called the London penetration depth. For physical materials it lies in the 10 − 200 nanometer range. A solution to these equations can be expressed, within Ω, via the Stratton-Chu formula, as an integral over the boundary of Ω (denoted by Γ) using the Green’s function
g i ΛL
(x,y) = e − |x−y| λL
4π|x− y| . (1.2)
From this formula it follows that the solution falls off like e− dist(x,Γ) λL , which, for physically reasonable values of λL, means that the solutions are almost zero outside of a very thin neighborhood of Γ.
Since ∇ · ∇ × V = 0 for any vector field V , (1.1) implies that
∇ ·B− = ∇ · J− = 0 . (1.3)
In the complementary region there is a static magnetic field Btot, which satisfies the usual magneto-static equations
∇×Btot = 0 and ∇ ·Btot = 0 in Ωc. (1.4)
While J− is supported in a thin neighborhood of Γ, there is no current sheet on the boundary of Ω, and so the physically reasonable boundary conditions are that
B− = Btot on Γ , (1.5)
i.e., the magnetic field is continuous across the boundary. This boundary condition and ∇×Btot = 0 imply that B− is a closed vector field on the manifold Γ and thus satisfies
∇Γ · ( n×B− ) = 0 on Γ . (1.6)
Here ∇Γ· denotes the surface divergence operator on the boundary Γ and n is the outward pointing unit normal (pointing into Ωc) to Γ. The London equation shows that J− · n = 0 is equivalent to ∇Γ ·n×B− = 0. This theory, at least in the static case, seems to be widely
accepted, see [2], though it is restricted to circumstances where the induced fields in the superconductor remain below the critical level.
In the standard “scattering” problem for this set-up there is an incoming magneto-static field Bin, so that, in Ωc, Btot = Bin + B+, where B+ is an outgoing field satisfying the radiation condition ∣∣∣B+(x)∣∣∣ = o(|x|−1). (1.7) The boundary conditions in (1.4) are then given by
B− = (B+ +Bin) on Γ. (1.8)
If the domain Ω is non-contractible, then this problem does not have a unique solution. If Γ has genus g, then there are g A-cycles {A1, . . . , Ag}, which bound surfaces {SA1 , . . . , SAg} contained within Ω, and g B-cycles {B1, . . . , Bg}, which bound surfaces {SB1 , . . . , SBg} contained in Ωc, see Fig. 1 for the genus 1 case.
Since −n × n × B is a closed vector field on Γ, its integrals over cycles on Γ depend only on the homology class of the cycle. It follows from the boundary condition, and Stokes theorem that∫
Bj B− · d` = ∫ Bj (B+ +Bin) · d` = ∫ SBj ∇× (B+ +Bin) · n dS = 0. (1.9)
On the other hand the fluxes aj = ∫ Aj B− · d` = ∫ SAj ∇×B− · n dS = ∫ SAj J− · n dS, for j = 1, . . . , g, (1.10)
are not determined a priori, and in fact, constitute additional data that must be specified to get a uniqueness theorem.

sections.heading: 2 The Uniqueness Theorem
sections.text:
Before proceeding to the uniqueness theorem we consider a minimal parametrization for solutions to this system of equations. The bounded domain Ω always has a trivial 2-
dimensional cohomology group, and therefore B− = ∇×A−, with A− a solution of
−∆A− = − 1 λ2L A−. (2.1)
We then define J− = ∇(∇ · A−) − 1 λ2L A−. With these choices, B− and J− satisfy the equations (1.1) and (1.3) . The set of vector fields satisfying (2.1) depend on 3 functions defined on Γ, for example −n × (n ×A−) and −∇ ·A−. Using the gauge freedom A− → A− +∇φ−, where λ2L∆φ− − φ− = 0, we can reduce this to two functions on the boundary.
There are g outgoing harmonic vector fields defined in Ωc, denoted by {BH1 , . . . ,BHg }, which satisfy ∇×BHj = ∇ ·BHj = 0 for x ∈ Ωc, and BHj · n = 0, for x ∈ Γ, j = 1, 2, . . . g. An arbitrary vector field B+, satisfying ∇×B+ = ∇ ·B+ = 0 has a unique representation as
B+ = ∇f+ + g∑ j=1 hjB H j , (2.2)
where ∆f+ = 0. Thus outgoing solutions to magneto-static problems depend on 1-function of mean 0 on Γ (∂nf+), and the g real numbers {h1, . . . , hg}.
We now state and prove a uniqueness theorem for this problem.
Theorem 1. Suppose that (B−,J−), and B+ satisfy (1.1) and (1.4) respectively and the homogeneous boundary conditions
B− = B+ on Γ , (2.3)
along with the conditions ∫ Aj B− · d` = 0 for j = 1, 2, . . . , g. (2.4)
If, in addition, B+ is an outgoing solution, then (B−,J−) ≡ (0, 0) in Ω and B+ ≡ 0, in Ωc.
Proof. We use integration parts. Using equation (1.1) and Stokes theorem we see that∫ Ω [ 1 λ2L |B−|2 + |J−|2 ] dV = ∫ Γ n×B− · J−dS. (2.5)
The hypotheses of the theorem imply that B+ has no projection onto the harmonic vector fields BHj , j = 1, 2, . . . g, and thus there exists a harmonic function f defined in Ωc such that B+ = ∇f. Therefore, as B+ is outgoing,∫
Ωc |B+|2dV = ∫ Ωc |∇f |2dV = − ∫ Γ fB+ · ndS , (2.6)
Note the extra negative sign since the normal is pointing into Ωc. Because B− = B+ on the boundary, we see that∫
Γ n×B− · J− = ∫ Γ n×∇f · J−dS
= ∫
Γ [−f∇× J− · n+∇× (fJ−) · n]
= 1 λ2L ∫ Γ fB+ · n.
(2.7)
Combining these various computations we see that∫ Ω [ 1 λ2L |B−|2 + |J−|2 ] dV + 1 λ2L ∫ Ωc |B+|2dV = 0, (2.8)
from which the conclusion is immediate.
The theorem shows thatBin(x) for x on Γ along with the g real parameters {a1, . . . , ag}, uniquely determine a solution to the “scattering” problem for a superconductor. Note that this theorem leaves open the possibility that there is g-parameter family of purely outgoing solutions. In the next section we will see that such solutions do in fact exist. In the physically important toroidal case, this theorem implies that the static current distribution in a superconducting torus is determined by its flux across SA.
This uniqueness result, in the simply connected case, appears in [2].

sections.heading: 5 Injectivity of the Debye Source Representation
sections.text:
We have shown that the Debye source representation results in a system of Fredholm equations of second kind, but we still need to show that this representation has a trivial nullspace. That is we need to show that if we are given data (q−, r−, l−H , q+, l + H) so that the equations (4.10)–(4.20) are all satisfied with right hand sides equal to zero, then the data itself must be zero. In this context we will assume that the incoming data Bin satisfies∫
Aj
Bin · d` = 0 for j = 1, . . . , g. (5.1)
This can always be arranged by adding an outgoing harmonic vector field to Bin. It follows from these assumptions that for x on Γ, Bin = 0, therefore the fields B± satisfy the homogeneous conditions
B+ = B− on Γ∫ Aj B− · d` = 0 for j = 1, . . . , g. (5.2)
Since B+ is outgoing, we proved above that these conditions imply that (J−,B−) = (0, 0) in Ω, and B+ = 0 in Ωc.
To show that the Debye representation is injective, we first considerB+ = ∇×A++∇Ψ+ in Ωc. The fact that this field vanishes shows that∫

Recall that A+ = ∫ Γ g0(x,y)l+H(y)dS, (5.4)
where l+H ∈ V+. The subspace V+ ⊂ H1(Γ) is defined so that the conditions satisfied by ∇×A+ imply that l+H ≡ 0, see (4.18). Thus we see that ∇Ψ+ = 0 for x ∈ Ωc, where

sections.heading: 6 J− is a Physical Current
sections.text:
In this section we prove that the field J− found by solving the London equation in Ω is, in fact, the physical current. By this we mean that the external field B+ is found by applying the Biot-Savart operator to J−. To establish this we need some notation, and further uniqueness results.
We begin with a uniqueness theorem.
Theorem 2. Let Ω ⊂ R3 be a bounded domain with smooth boundary. Suppose that B ∈ C0(R3), satisfies
∇×B = 0, ∇ ·B = 0 in R3 \ Γ (6.1)
and B(x) = O(|x|−1), as x→∞, then B ≡ 0.
Proof. The first observation is that B must actually be a smooth harmonic vector field in all of R3. A simple integration by parts argument shows that B is a distributional solution to ∆B = 0, and so, by elliptic regularity it is a classical solution. Since ∇×B = 0 in R3 it follows that
f(x) = ∫ x
0 B · d` (6.2)
is a well defined function that satisfies
∇f = B, ∆f = 0 and |f(x)| = O(| log |x||) as |x| → ∞. (6.3)
The sharp form of Liouville’s theorem implies that f is constant, which completes the proof of the theorem.
As a corollary we see that the solution to the following transmission problem, with given J− in Ω and Bin on Γ has a unique solution
∇×B− = J−, ∇ ·B− =0 in Ω , ∇×B+ = 0, ∇ ·B+ =0 in [Ω]c with |B+(x)| = O(|x|−1) , B− −B+ = Bin on Γ

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text:
In this note we have studied the standard scattering problem for a static, low-field, type-I superconductor using the standard London equation formulation within the superconducting material. Amongst other things, we have shown that, for a superconductor of genus g > 0, the fluxes through the A-cycles can be specified arbitrarily and uniquely determine a current distribution and a corresponding external, outgoing magnetic field. Moreover this field can be obtained by applying the Biot-Savart formula to the current within the superconductor.
We have shown that, for any λL > 0, the Debye source formulation provides boundary integral equations, which are Fredholm equations of second-kind, that can be solved for an arbitrary incoming field and fluxes through the A-cycles. In numerical examples, we demonstrate the practical efficacy of this method, provided λL is not too small. In real applications λL is typically quite small, and the equations given in this paper will become very difficult to solve. In a second paper, see [4], we show that these equations have limits, in the strong operator sense, as λL → 0+. The limiting system of equations is nearly decoupled and consists of Fredholm equations, some of first kind and some of second kind. These equations can easily be solved and will provide an effective means to accurately approximate the solutions to (1.1), (1.4), (1.5) in physically reasonable cases.
